title: Ethereum CLI - Windows - runtime: out of memory: cannot allocate 1073741824-byte block
body:
I have encountered out-of-memory issues trying to use the Go Ethereum CLI to test mining on Windows 8 64-bit.  This binary was built by me today using the latest develop branch code.  It crashes immediately after finishing DAG generation, when executing with ethereum -mine

Standard output:

```
Welcome to the FRONTIER
2015/03/25 21:55:18 [SERV] Protocol Version: 59, Network Id: 0
```

My system certainly has no shortage of RAM, so this is rather puzzling:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8011332/6825673/942ed582-d33f-11e4-87bc-91c459fd30dd.png)

Note that I previously was not able to even get as far as generating the DAG due to another out-of-memory error, as I commented on issue #545.  I was able to get around that by applying the Windows 4GB memory patch (http://www.ntcore.com/4gb_patch.php) to get around default memory limits imposed on 32-bit processes by the operating system (see http://www.viva64.com/en/k/0036/ for background reading).  But apparently that didn't completely fix the issue, as I'm now stuck again.

Here are some screen shots on memory usage I captured from Task Manager and Resource Monitor immediately before the crash:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8011332/6825786/4e9b62c8-d340-11e4-853a-3540fa82c80e.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8011332/6825800/5fbb77aa-d340-11e4-9a8a-ca9e5215e173.png)

It looks like the Ethereum CLI simply demands too much memory under Windows for a 32-bit application to handle.  Compiling as a native 64-bit application would probably fix it.

File handling is currently done by Go (storing the DAG to disk) and requires an enormous amount of ram because it needs to copy bytes to Go-land.

The solution we're currently working on is to move file handling completely to the C lib. Hang in tight! :-)
I had too move to my comp with 32gb of RAM. Nice to know this is being addressed, cheers!
Okay, good to hear you've got a plan, thanks for the reply.
